Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: The Influence of Distributed River Inputs and Coastal Embayments on Dynamics in Large Estuaries
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project is designed to transform the understanding of the effects of distributed rivers and coastal embayments on dynamics in large estuaries like the Long Island Sound (LIS). The hypotheses to be tested are: 1) Wind-driven and tidal straining of across-estuary density gradients is quantitatively as large as straining of along-estuary gradients; 2) Distributed river inputs create focused areas of increased straining and areas of reversed straining conditions; 3) During storm response, smaller river inputs from coastal watersheds collectively have a first-order influence on circulation and density structure; 4) River waters follow regular transport pathways that shift during wind events; 5) Coastal embayments transition from areas of net mixing to increased stratification as tidal currents decrease along the estuary. The hydrodynamic simulations for the LIS will be coupled to a surface-runoff model for coastal watersheds. Straining conditions and the combined influence of the smaller river inflows will be studied to determine the transport pathways for fresh water from the distributed river inputs and quantify the effects of coastal embayments on estuarine circulation and density structure.

Intellectual Merit: The proposed modeling research will transform the understanding of dynamics in large estuaries. The study will advance the understanding of how fresh water from multiple sources combines to determine estuary density fields; tracking these separate inputs also informs the study of riverine nutrient, contaminant, and carbon inputs to estuaries. The research will extend the study of estuarine density straining to large estuaries where a 3D approach is necessary and spatial variations in straining conditions are pronounced. Inputs from distributed smaller rivers from coastal watersheds will be accurately represented using a coupled surface-runoff model and an input method consistent with potential energy considerations. This study will quantify the effects of these smaller distributed rivers and coastal embayments on large-scale estuarine dynamics. The new coupled modeling approach and analysis techniques will increase the ability to model present and future estuarine conditions. The integrated multi-faceted education and outreach effort each year will inform several hundred K-12 students, undergraduates, graduate students, and the general public on estuarine dynamics, storm response, and research results. The main message that nearby rivers and embayments have far-reaching effects should foster interest in and encourage stewardship of the coastal watersheds and estuaries.

Broader Impacts: This project will train a post-doctoral researcher and undergraduate student for careers in scientific research and education. Undergraduate and graduate students will be educated by the new 'Freshwater Transport and Mixing' course. Summer undergraduate interns will gain vital research experience. Several hundred students reached by the K-12 education and outreach efforts, through the Project Oceanology field education program and the annual 'Meet Your Estuary Day' for lower-income and minority students, will gain an understanding of the interconnectedness of watersheds and estuaries and a new interest in studying and protecting coastal waters. The new college course and the new Project Oceanology learning module developed will continue beyond the project span; adding to the project?s educational legacy. Research findings will inform research for large estuaries and compliment research on environmental issues facing LIS and other estuaries. This project will inform biogeochemical research on multiple riverine inputs of nutrients, pollutants, and carbon to estuarine systems. The coupling techniques combining the surface-runoff and hydrodynamic models will be shared with the coastal modeling community. Results will be published in scientific journals and presented at conferences. The program will improve the scientific infrastructure at the University of Connecticut and will improve partnerships between the university, Project Oceanology, Connecticut Sea Grant and other organizations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project advanced the understanding of how distributed rivers and coastal embayments interact in large estuaries like Long Island Sound, a large urbanized estuary on the US east coast.  The research methods relied on hydrodynamic estuary-shelf simulations coupled with a watershed model and, in some cases, an atmospheric model.  New observations of surface drifter tracks and existing long-term observations of water properties were used to assess model results.

The Connecticut River is Long Island Sound’s largest freshwater source.  It enters close to the estuary mouth, an unusual situation relative to many estuaries where most rivers enter near the head.  A major project outcome is simulation results indicate that Connecticut River water is found throughout the estuary and is the predominant contributor to the freshwater composition in most parts of the estuary.  Furthermore, simulation results show the Connecticut River water follows two pathways towards the head.  In the spring, when river flow is strong, its waters can remain near the surface as a relatively fresh (low salinity) plume traveling along the coast towards the estuary head.  This pathway was substantiated with observed surface drifters.  In the summer, when river flow is weaker, some of its waters move towards the head only after being mixed to the bottom and joining with the near-bottom inflow of saltier waters.  Connecticut River waters can remain in the estuary for several seasons.  It eventually joins the near-surface outflow traveling along the other side of the estuary towards the mouth.  Winds blowing towards the mouth are prevalent during fall and winter.  The associated wind-driven flows block transport of Connecticut River waters towards the head.  The other major pathway for Connecticut River water is towards the mouth and ultimately onto the shelf.  The proportion of freshwater following the pathway shifts seasonally, but it is important throughout the year and was repeatedly observed with surface drifters. 

Another outcome is the revealed importance of topographic effects, particularly near Mattituck Sill (an area of shallower depths stretching across the estuary).  Tides interacting with the sill topography generate currents that circulate clockwise around the sill.  This circulation increases across-estuary transport of fresh waters.  The sill also acts as a partial barrier to near-bottom transport towards the head.  Conditions most favor transport up and over the sill after neap (weaker than normal) tides.  Consequently, the summer transport of Connecticut River waters along with the salty near-bottom inflow occurs in pulses.

The intermediate river inflows and smaller coastal rivers are distributed throughout Long Island Sound.  A major project outcome based on simulation results indicates that fresh water from the intermediate rivers is most concentrated closer to the estuary head.  These freshwaters are the strongest contributors to vertical stratification (the layering of less dense over denser waters) near the head.  The smaller coastal rivers only have an appreciable influence on lowering salinities and increasing stratification in a narrow band along the coast.  The influence of small coastal rivers is amplified immediately following major rain events due to shorter storm response times relative to the larger rivers.  The typical time river waters spend in the estuary (the freshwater residence time) varies seasonally and from river to river.  Results indicate the freshwater residence times tend to increase towards the estuary head.

Project efforts on embayments focused on waters inshore of the Norwalk Islands in western Long Island Sound.  A major project outcome is quantifying (with observations and simulations) the strong role that summertime cooling by offshore waters plays in countering surface heating and keeping embayment water temperatures much lower than they otherwise would be.   The nearshore water temperatures nevertheless remain higher than offshore throughout the summer.  The shallow depths is the primary factor favoring warmer temperatures.  This influence overcomes the summertime cooling influence that the offshore islands augment by promoting more tidal exchange with cooler offshore waters.

Broader impacts to physical oceanography include a new understanding of physical dynamics in Long Island Sound, which can be applied to other large estuaries.  Project research has had impacts on chemical oceanography by allowing for riverine pollutant tracking and source-attribution.  Also the fluxes from the simulation results have been combined with observations to calculate nutrient and carbon budgets for the estuary and export to the continental shelf.  Project research also has had impacts on environmental management of commercial shellfisheries and seafood safety by applying modeled temperature and salinity fields to forecasting harmful bacteria levels in oysters.

The educational/outreach outcomes educated and trained PhD students, undergraduate interns, graduate and undergraduate students, and K-12 students.  These efforts included developing and teaching a new undergraduate/graduate course “River Influences in the Marine Environment”, hosting a “Meet Your Estuary Day” for inner-city high-school students in the early years of the project, developing an estuary storm response learning module for middle-school students, and conducting estuary-science demonstrations for elementary-school students at the annual “Math & Science Day.”
